titleStmt.title: A letter from his Excellency the Lord Fairfax Generall of the Parliaments forces: concerning the surrender of Colchester, the grounds and reasons of putting to death Sir Charles Lucas and Sir George Lysle; with the articles and explanation of the same. Together with a list of all the prisoners taken, their numbers and qualities therein exprest. Read in the House of Peeres upon the 31 of Aug. 1648. And commanded to be printed and published.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A LETTER From his Excellency the Lord Fairfax Generall of the PARLIAMENTS FORCES: Concerning the Å¿urrender of COLCHESTER, THE Grounds and ReaÅ¿ons of putting to death Sir CHARLES LUCAS and Sir GEORGE LYSLE; with the Articles and Explanation of the Å¿ame.
Together with a LiÅ¿t of all the PriÅ¿oners taken, their numbers and qualities therein expreÅ¿t.
Read in the HouÅ¿e of Peeres upon the 31 of Aug. 1648. And commanded to be printed and publiÅ¿hed.
Imprinted at London, for John Wright at the Kings Head in the old Bayley, 2 Septemb. 1648.

div.head: For the Right Honourable Edward Earl of MancheÅ¿ter, Speaker of the HouÅ¿e of Peeres Pro Tempore.
div.p: I Have herewith Å¿ent you the Articles, with the Explanations annexed, upon which it hath pleaÅ¿ed God in his beÅ¿t time to deliver the Town of ColcheÅ¿ter, and the enemy therein into your hands without further bloudÅ¿hed, Å¿aving that (for Å¿ome Å¿atisfaction to Military JuÅ¿tice, and in part of avenge for the innocent bloud they have cauÅ¿ed to be Å¿pilt, and the trouble, damage, and miÅ¿chiefe they have brought upon the Towne, this Country, and the Kingdome) I have with the advice of a CounÅ¿ell of Warre of the chiefe Officers both of the Country Forces and the Army, cauÅ¿ed two of them who were rendred at mercy to be Å¿hot to death before any of them had Quarter aÅ¿Å¿ured them. The perÅ¿ons pitched upon for this example were, Sir Charles Lucas, and Sir George LiÅ¿le, in whoÅ¿e Military execution I hope your LordÅ¿hips will not finde cauÅ¿e to thinke your Honour or JuÅ¿tice prejudiced. As for the Lord Goring, Lord Capell, and the reÅ¿t of the perÅ¿ons rendred to mercy, and now aÅ¿Å¿ured of Quarter; of whoÅ¿e names I have Å¿ent your LordÅ¿hips a particular LiÅ¿t. I doe hereby render to the Parliaments judgement for further publique JuÅ¿tice and Mercy to be uÅ¿ed as you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e. I deÅ¿ire God may have the glory of his multiplyed mercies towards you and the Kingdome in this kinde, and in the condition of inÅ¿truments as to the Å¿ervice here, the Officers and Souldiers of EÅ¿Å¿ex and Suffolke (who in this time of Å¿o dangerous defection have adhered conÅ¿tant to yours and the Kingdomes intereÅ¿t) for their faithfull demeaÅ¿nour and patient indurance in the hardÅ¿hips of this Å¿ervice are not to be forgotten.

closer.signed: Your LordÅ¿hips moÅ¿t humble Servant T. Fairfax.

div.head: Articles agreed upon the 27 of Aug. 1648. by and betweene the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of his Excellency the Lord Generall Fairfax on th'one part, and the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of the Earl of Norwich, Lord Capell, and Sir Charles Lucas on the other part, for and concerning the Rendition of the Town and GarriÅ¿on of ColcheÅ¿ter.
div.p: I. THat all the horÅ¿es belonging to the Officers, Souldiers, and Gentlemen ingaged in ColoheÅ¿ter, with Saddles and Bridles to them, Å¿hall be brought into Maries Church-yard by nine of the Clock to morrow morning, and the Å¿pare Saddles and Bridles into that Church, and delivered without wilfull Å¿poyle to firch as the Lord Generall Å¿hall appoint to take charge of them.

II. That all the Arms, Colours, and Drums belonging to any of the perÅ¿ons in ColcheÅ¿ter above mentioned, Å¿hall be brought into St. James Church by ten of the Clock to morrow morning and delivered without wilfull Å¿poyle or imbeazlment to Å¿uch as the Lord Generall Å¿hall appoint to take charge of them.

III. That all private Souldiers and Officers under Captaines, Å¿hall be drawne together into the Fryers yard adjoyning to the EaÅ¿t Gate by ten of the Clock to morrow morning with their Clothes and Baggage, their perÅ¿ons to be rendred into the cuÅ¿tody of Å¿uch as the Lord Generall Å¿hall appoint to take charge of them, and that they Å¿hall have faire Quarter according to the explanation made in the anÅ¿wer to the firÅ¿t Quaere of the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioniers from ColcheÅ¿ter which is hereunto annexed.

IV. That the Lords, and all Captaines, and Å¿uperiour Officers, and Gentlemen of quality ingaged in ColcheÅ¿ter, Å¿hall be drawne together to the Kings Head, with their Clothes and Buggage by eleven of the Clock to morrow morning, and there render themÅ¿elves to the mercy of the Lord Generall, into the hands of Å¿uch as he Å¿hall appoint to take charge of them, and that a LiÅ¿t of the names of all the generall Officers, and Field-Officers now in command in the Towne be Å¿ent out to the Lord Generall by nine of the Clock in the morning.

V. That all the Guards within the Towne of ColcheÅ¿ter Å¿hall be with-drawne from the Line, Forts, and other places by eight of the Clock to morrow morning, and Å¿uch as the Lord Generall Å¿hall appoint Å¿hall thereupon come into their roomes.

VI. That all the Ammunition Å¿hall be preÅ¿erved in the places where it lyes, to be delivered to the Comptroller of his Excellencies Traine by ten of the Clock to morrow morning; and all the Waggons belonging to the Souldery, or perÅ¿ons engaged, with the HarneÅ¿Å¿e belonging thereunto, Å¿hall be brought to Å¿ome convenient place neare the Ammunition, to be delivered to the Å¿ame perÅ¿on by the Å¿ame houre.

VII. That Å¿uch as are wounded and Å¿ick in the Towne Å¿hall be there kept and provided for, with accommodation requiÅ¿ite for men in their condition, and not removed thence untill they be recovered, or able without prejudice to their healths to remove, and Å¿hall have Å¿uch Chyrurgions allowed to looke to them as are now in the Towne.

VIII. That all Ordnance in the Towne, with their appurtinances Å¿hall without wilfull Å¿poyle be left at the Å¿everall Platformes, or places where they are now planted, and Å¿o delivered to his Excellencies Guard that Å¿hall take the charge of thoÅ¿e places reÅ¿pectively.

IX. That from henceforth there Å¿hall be a CeÅ¿Å¿ation of Arms on hoth parts, but the Forces within the Town to keep their own Guards, and the Lord Generalls to keepe theirs untill they Å¿hall be removed according to the Articles afore-going.

Signed by Us

THo. Honywood

div.head: Quaeries propounded by the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners from ColcheÅ¿ter, to the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of his Excellency the Lord Fairfax, upon the Conditions Å¿ent into the Towne.
div.p: 1. WHat is meant by faire Quarter?
2. What by rendring to Mercy?

To the firÅ¿t. BY faire Quarter we underÅ¿tand, That with Quarter for their lives they Å¿hall be free from wounding or beating; Å¿hall enjoy warme clothes to cover them and keep them warme; Å¿hall be maintained with victuals fit for priÅ¿oners while they Å¿hall be kept priÅ¿oners.

To the Å¿econd. By rendring to mercy we underÅ¿tand, That they be rendred or render themÅ¿elves to the Lord Generall, or whom he Å¿hall appoint, without certaine aÅ¿Å¿urance of Quarter, Å¿o as the Lord Generall may be free to put Å¿ome immediately to the Å¿word (if he Å¿ee cauÅ¿e) although his Excellency intends chiefly and for the generality of thoÅ¿e under that condition, to Å¿urrender them to the mercy of the Parliament and Generall. There hath been large experience, neither hath his Excellency given cauÅ¿e to doubt of his civility to Å¿uch as he Å¿hall retaine priÅ¿oners, although by their being rendred to mercy, he Å¿tands not engaged thereby.

div.head: Upon returne of theÅ¿e AnÅ¿wers the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners from ColcheÅ¿ter propounded theÅ¿e two further Quaeries.
div.p: 1. VVHether theÅ¿e that were Å¿urrendred to mercy, Å¿hall enjoy their wearing clothes, as well thoÅ¿e on their backs, as what other change they have.
2. Whether the Noblemen and Officers Å¿hall have uÅ¿e of their owne HorÅ¿es to the places where they Å¿hall be confined.
To which was anÅ¿wered by his Excellencies CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners.
To the firÅ¿t. IT is intended that thoÅ¿e who Å¿hall be tendred and received to mercy, Å¿hall enjoy the wearing clothes on their backs; but for more the Generall will not be ingaged.

To the Å¿econd. It is expected (in caÅ¿e of Å¿urrender upon Treaty) That all HorÅ¿es as well as Arms be delivered up, and for circumÅ¿tances thereof there is to be an Article yet for the Gentlemen and Officers under this condition in queÅ¿tion, (when any of them Å¿hall be removed to the places of confinement) his Excellency will take care for HorÅ¿es to carry them (with reÅ¿pect to their qualities,) but for allowing their owne HorÅ¿es he will not be ingaged.

div.head: A LiÅ¿t of the PriÅ¿oners taken at the Å¿urrender of ColcheÅ¿ter the 28 of AuguÅ¿t. 1648.
